editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Therefore the holy nor the most holy, the true nor the mo≈øt true light (which the most highest hath pre≈øently in his mo≈øt holy ≈øeruice vnder the obedience of the loue geuen vnto vs, for to be declared forth) hath not Heb. 9. b. 10. a. bene declared by any of theÃÑ all, that haue taken on, ≈øet forth, and taught any thyng before this ≈øame or without this ≈øame our ≈øeruice of the loue. in his word,Theophilus vttereth an vntruth wittingly. 1. chap. 7. ≈øenten. wheÃÑ as the fayth of their Familie (HN. I meane) in the booke by him intituled. As for me and tho≈øe that de≈øire not hand ouer head to receiue all that comes from euery maÃÑ, it is ≈øufficient and ≈øhalbe that if they laui≈øh out any vntruth, that I be pardoned for not ≈øealyng vnto it, before I way it in Gods ballance, lea≈øt it proue light, and try it at the touch≈øtone lea≈øt it be counterfeite.

WHy then haue ye left the Churche, into the which ye were Bapti≈øed? why did ye promi≈øe ye would manfully fight vnder Chri≈øtes banner, and continue his faythfull ≈øouldiour and ≈øeruaunt to your liues end,HN. and his ≈øchollers traytors of Chri≈øtes Church. and now lyke a runnagate Apo≈øtata & a cowardly ≈øouldiour or rather a traiterous Iudas ye betray his Saints to SathaÃÑ, & breake truce with the ≈øon of God, into who≈øe obedience ye were ≈øworne? you to frame and imagine to your ≈øelfe a new Churche? For whereas ≈øo ofteÃÑ you affirme, that you haue no church but ours, no a≈ø≈øemblies but ours, why doth HN. terme it our Familie or ≈øeruice? doth not this word, our Familie, note a particular ≈øecte or faction in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a few. Euang. cap. 4. ≈øent. 5.NO maÃÑ (≈øayth HN.) how wi≈øe ≈øoeuer he be in the knowledge of the Scriptures, can by any meane vnder≈øtand or comprehend the wi≈øedome of God,Sent. 7. 1. Exhort. chap. 16. ≈øent. 16. but onely they that be of the Familie: who ≈øoeuer is without the Familie is inueigled with wiles, ≈øubtletie, and fal≈øechode. div.head: ARTICLE. 3. of HN. No Bapti≈øme.
div.p: WIthout the Familye of Loue (≈øayth HN) there is no true Chri≈øtian Bapti≈øme.1. Exhort. cap. 7. ≈øent. 10.11.32. fol. 12. and. cap. 12. ≈øent. 44. fol. 27.
This ≈øame is the ≈øchole of grace, to an euerlasting remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes ouer all ≈øuch as cleaue there vnder.
There is no true Chri≈øtianitye but the Comminalty of the holy ones in the loue of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. Ion. 17. c. Ephe. 4. a. h.&. cap. 16. ≈øent. 20. fol. 43.

All other that haue not the Chri≈øtian doctrine of the ≈øeruice of the loue forgoing their Bapti≈øme, It is not meete and conuenient, that men ≈øhould count ≈øuch vnbeleuers, and vnbapti≈øed ones for Chri≈øtians: neither yet al≈øo for men, at who≈øe handes one ≈øhould any way ≈øuppo≈øe or tru≈øt to finde any word of Ioh. 1. a. 3. a. gods truth or yet any workes Mar. 1. a. righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe or Gods ≈øeruice,Euang. cap. 23. ≈øent. 7. &. cap. 4. ≈øent. 57. that God regardeth or accepteth. COn≈øider better of the text. Rather vnder the obedience of the father and his loue, vnder the obedience of Chri≈øt, and his beliefe, and the obedience of the holy gho≈øt, and his renewing of the lyfe, and minde &c. to be bapti≈øed in the name of the father, the ≈øonne, and the holy gho≈øt. &c.

WHat account HN. maketh of our Church, and the truth therein taught, is already declared. Now
followeth it to be vnder≈øtode, what his opinion is of our Sacramentes. And fir≈øt to ≈øpeake of bapti≈øme (For of the holy Sacrament of the ≈øupper of our Lord he hath written very litle) what he attributeth to our Church therein is playne, that vnle≈ø≈øe we haue our foregoing in the doctrine of the loue, we are not to be counted of him, and his Fam, to be bapti≈øed ones. To the which I will aun≈øwere briefly, if fir≈øt he ≈øhall ≈øati≈øfy me in this demaund: Whether when there was no Family of Loue, there were no vpright bapti≈øme in England? If he ≈øay there was a lawfull bapti≈øme, than is there an vpright bapti≈øme without the foregoing of his louely doctrine, and without his Family a true Chri≈øtian bapti≈øme. Ibid. 6. leafe. v. that they doe deale ≈øimply, and playnely. &c, We haue (≈øay they,) nor v≈øe any other Ceremonyes, lawes, ≈øtatutes, nor Sacramentes: of Bapti≈øme, and ≈øupper of the Lord, then ≈øuch as are mini≈øtred in the Church of England. But I ≈øay that the Church of England v≈øeth not rebaptization. Therefore if they be rebapti≈øed, they be double faced di≈ø≈øemblers. Furthermore if they ≈øhall affirme that they v≈øe not other Sacramentes &c. than is v≈øed in the Church of England, that is: in their Fam. in the Church of England, becau≈øe it was ≈øayd in the fir≈øt Article, that we haue no Church without their Family: I aun≈øwere: They pretend in their confe≈ø≈øion, they deale faythfully with all men: If this be their fayth, what I pray you

And thus much for this Article is ≈øufficient. As for you frend Theophilus, ye huddle vp ≈øo, that no man can vnder≈øtand you: when you ≈øhall learne to ≈øpeake out of the mouth, and leaue to fumble with your. &c. I will tell you my minde more art large.

HN. Reproueth our doctrine with this terme,HN. Euang. cap. 19. ≈øent. 5.6. and handful of water, an Elementi≈øh water. Cor. 6. b. there is no ≈øuch thyng, nor any ≈øteppe of ≈øuch a ≈øence as he ≈ø√©emeth to alledge it for. div.head: ARTICLE. 5. HN. No Mini≈øtery.
div.p: WE mu≈øt haue respect vnto the ≈øeruice mini≈øtred in the Familie by the Elders thereof.1. Exhort. cap. 12. ≈øent. 40.41.42.43.44. &. cap. 16. ≈øent. 16. Thus then not euery one that pretendeth is called in d√©ede, for ≈øome come not in at the doore, but clyme in at the windowes, and as many as come before Chri≈øt, and ≈øet downe a contrary requiryng (as ye do) he is a Wolfe & ≈ø√©eketh but to rauin. Yet if any man ≈øhall ≈øay well and doe euill (whiche God forefend) with man it may di≈øcredit him that doth ≈øpeake well and yet do ami≈ø≈øe: with God euill d√©edes doe not di≈øanull the truth of doctrine, as good d√©edes proue not euill doctrine to be true. So then this rea≈øon that in corners your froward Familye v≈øeth to whi≈øper agayn≈øt euill men (though Gods Mini≈øters) is Anabapti≈øticall.Bullen. 2. boke. 7. chap. leafe. 97. Your Mini≈øters liue not as they teach. Therefore their doctrine is not true. In Scripture I know this rea≈øon is often v≈øed: Your lyfe is not according to the law & your profe≈ø≈øion: E≈øay. 58. The ≈øame rea≈øon is by your Familye, and by your good minded brethren the Papi≈øtes alledged agayn≈øt the truth, now preached after this ≈øort. Euang. cap. 13. ≈øent. 4. whereof the one will be ≈øaued by the fulfilling of the lawe, the other will haue markes concurre with fayth in the matter of Iu≈øtification, cleane contrary to S. Augu≈øtine who ≈øayth, Opera ≈øequuntur iu≈øtificatum, non praecedunt iu≈øtificandum. The workes we doe follow as fruites and goe
